Original post:

Although I concluded my previous post by saying that I would not write anything more about CPT symmetry, I feel like I have done an injustice to Val Fitch, James Cronin, and all those other researchers who spent many man-years to painstakingly demonstrate how the weak force does not always respect the combined charge-parity (C-P) symmetry. Indeed, I did not want to denigrate their efforts when I noted that:

These decaying kaons (i.e. the particles that are used to demonstrate the CP symmetry-breaking phenomenon) are rather exotic and very short-lived particles; and

Researchers have not been able to find many other traces of non-respect of CP symmetry, except when studying a heavier version of these kaons (the so-called B- and D-mesons) as soon as these could be produced in higher volumes in newer (read: higher-energy) particle colliders (so thatâ€™s in the last ten or fifteen years only), but so these B- and D-mesons are even more rare and even less stable.

CP violation is CP violation: itâ€™s plain weird, especially when Fermilab and CERN experiments observed direct CP violation in kaon decay processes. [Remember that the original 1964 Fitch-Cronin experiment could not directly observe CP violation: in their experiment, CP violation in neutral kaon decay processes could only be deduced from other (unexpected) decay processes.]

Why? When one reverses all of the charges and other variables (such as parity which â€“ let me remind you â€“ has to do with â€˜left-handednessâ€™ and â€˜right-handednessâ€™ of particles), then the process should go in the other direction in an exactly symmetric way. Full stop. If not, thereâ€™s some kind of â€˜leakageâ€™ so to say, and such â€˜leakageâ€™ would be â€˜kind-of-OKâ€™ when weâ€™d be talking some kind of chemical or biological process, but itâ€™s obviously not â€˜kind-of-OKâ€™ when weâ€™re talking one of the fundamental forces. Itâ€™s just not â€˜logicalâ€™.

Feynman versus â€˜t Hooft: pro and contra CP-symmetry breaking

A remark that is much more relevant than the two comments above is that one of the most brilliant physicists of the 20th century, Richard Feynman, seemed to have refused to entertain the idea of CP-symmetry breaking. Indeed, while, in his 1965 Lectures, he devotes quite a bit of attention to Chien-Shiung Wuâ€™s 1956 experiment with decaying cobalt-60 nuclei (i.e. the experiment which first demonstrated parity violation, i.e. the breaking of P-symmetry), he does not mention the 1964 Fitch-Cronin experiment, and all of his writing in these Lectures makes it very clear that he not only strongly believes that the combined CP symmetry holds, but that itâ€™s also the only â€˜symmetryâ€™ that matters really, and the only one that Nature truly respectsâ€“always.

So Feynman was wrong. Of course, these Lectures were published less than a year after the 1964 Fitch-Cronin experiment and, hence, you might think he would have changed his ideas on the possibility of Nature not respecting CP-symmetryâ€“just like Wolfgang Pauli, who could only accept the reality of Nature not respecting reflection symmetry (P-symmetry) after repeated experiments re-confirmed the results of Wuâ€™s original 1956 experiment.

But â€“ No! â€“ Feynmanâ€™s 1985 book on quantum electrodynamics (QED) â€“so thatâ€™s five years after Fitch and Cronin got a Nobel Prize for their discoveryâ€“ is equally skeptical on this point: he basically states that the weak force is â€œnot well understoodâ€ and that he hopes that â€œa more beautiful and, hence, more accurate understandingâ€ of things will emerge.

OK, you will say, but Feynman passed away shortly after (he died from a rare form of cancer in 1988) and, hence, we should now listen to the current generation of physicists.

Youâ€™re obviously right, so letâ€™s look around. Hmmâ€¦ Gerard â€˜t Hooft? Yes ! He is 67 now but â€“ despite his age â€“ it is obvious that he surely qualifies as a â€˜next-generationâ€™ physicist. He got his Nobel Prize for â€œelucidating the quantum structure of electroweak interactionsâ€ (read: for clarifying how the weak force actually works) and he is also very enthusiastic about all these Grand Unified Theories (most notably string and superstring theory) and so, yes, he should surely know, shouldnâ€™t he?

I guess so. However, even â€˜t Hooft writes that these experiments with these â€˜crazy kaonsâ€™ â€“ as he calls them â€“ show â€˜violationâ€™ indeed, but that itâ€™s marginal: the very same experiments also show near-symmetry. Whatâ€™s near-symmetry? Wellâ€¦ Just what the term says: the weak force is almost symmetrical. Hence, CP-symmetry is the norm and CP-asymmetry is only a marginal phenomenon. That being said, itâ€™s there and, hence, it should be explained. How?

â€˜t Hooft himself writes that one could actually try to interpret the results of the experiment by adding some kind of â€˜fifthâ€™ force to our world view â€“ a â€œsuper-weak forceâ€ as he calls it, which would interfere with the weak force only.

To be fair, he immediately adds that introducing such â€˜fifth forceâ€™ doesnâ€™t really solve the â€œmysteryâ€ of CP asymmetry, because, while weâ€™d restore the principle of CP symmetry for the weak force interactions, we would then have to explain why this â€˜super-weakâ€™ force does not respect it. In short, we cannot just reason the problem away. Hence, â€˜t Hooftâ€™s conclusion in his 1996 book on The Ultimate Building Blocks of the universe is quite humble: â€œThe deeper cause [of CP asymmetry] is likely to remain a mystery.â€ (â€˜t Hooft, 1996, Chapter 7: The crazy kaons)

What about other explanations? For example, you might be tempted to think these two or three exceptions to a thousand cases respecting the general rule must have something to do with quantum-mechanical uncertainty: when everything is said and done, weâ€™re dealing with probabilities in quantum mechanics, arenâ€™t we? Hence, exceptions do occur and are actually expected to occur.

No. Quantum indeterminism is not applicable here. While working with probability amplitudes and probabilities is effectively equivalent to stating some general rules involving some average or mean value and then some standard deviation from that average, weâ€™ve got something else going on here: Fitch and Cronin took a full six months indeedâ€“repeating the experiment over and over and over againâ€“to firmly establish a statistically significant bias away from the theoretical average. Hence, even if the bias is only 0.2% or 0.3%, it is a statistically significant difference between the probability of a process going one way, and the probability of that very same process going the other way.

So what? There are so many non-reversible processes and asymmetries in this world: why donâ€™t we just accept this?Wellâ€¦ Iâ€™ll just refer to my previous post on this one: weâ€™re talking a fundamental force here â€“ not some chemical reaction â€“ and, hence, if we reverse all of the relevant charges (including things such as left-handed or right-handed spin), the reaction should go the other way, and with exactly the same probability. If it doesnâ€™t, itâ€™s plain weird. Full stop.

OK. [â€¦] Butâ€¦ Perhaps there is some external phenomenon affecting these likelihoods, like these omnipresent solar neutrinos indeed, which I mentioned in a previous post and which are all left-handed. So perhaps we should allow these to enter the equation as well. [â€¦] Wellâ€¦ I already said that would make senseâ€“to some extent at leastâ€“ because there is some flimsy evidence of solar flares affecting radioactive decay rates (solar flares and neutrino outbursts are closely related, so if solar flares impact radioactive decay, we could or should expect them to meddle with any beta decay process really). That being said, it would not make sense from other, more conventional, points of view: we cannot just â€˜addâ€™ neutrinos to the equation because then weâ€™d be in trouble with the conservation laws, first and foremost the energy conservation law! So, even if we would be able to work out some kind of theoretical mechanism involving these left-handed solar neutrinos (which are literally all over the place, bombarding us constantly even if theyâ€™re very hard to detect), thus explaining the observed P-asymmetry, we would then have to explain why it violates the energy conservation law! Wellâ€¦ Good luck with that, Iâ€™d say!

So it is a conundrum really. Let me sum up the above discussion in two bullet points:

While kaons are short-lived particles because of the presence of the second-generation (and, hence, unstable) s-quark, they are real particles (so they are not some resonance or some so-called virtual particle). Hence, studying their behavior in interactions with any force field (and, most notably, their behavior in regard to the weak force) is extremely relevant, and the observed CP asymmetryâ€“no matter how smallâ€“is something which should really grab our attention.

The philosophical implications of any form of non-respect of the combined CP symmetry for our common-sense notion of time are truly profound and, therefore, the Fitch-Cronin experiment rightly deserves a lot of accolades.

So letâ€™s analyze these â€˜philosophical implicationsâ€™ (which is just a somewhat â€˜chargedâ€™ term for the linkage between CP- and time-symmetry which I want to discuss here) somewhat more in detail.

Time reversal and CPT symmetry

In the previous posts, I said itâ€™s probably useful to distinguish (a) time-reversal as a (loosely defined) philosophical concept from (b) the mathematical definition of time-reversal, which is much more precise and unambiguous. Itâ€™s the latter which is generally used in physics, and it amounts to putting a minus sign in front of all time variables in any equation describing some situation, process or system in physics. Thatâ€™s it really. Nothing more.

The point that I wanted to make is that true time reversal â€“ i.e. time-reversal in the â€˜philosophicalâ€™ or â€˜common-senseâ€™ interpretation â€“ also involves a reversal of the forces, and thatâ€™s done through reversing all charges causing those forces. I used the example of the movie as a metaphor: most movies, when played backwards, do not make sense, unless we reverse the forces. For example, seeing an object â€˜fall backâ€™ to where it was (before it started falling) in a movie playing backwards makes sense only if we would assume that masses repel, instead of attract, each other. Likewise, any static or dynamic electromagnetic phenomena we would see in that backwards playing movie would make sense only if we would assume that the charges of the protons and electrons causing the electromagnetic fields involved would be reversed. How? Wellâ€¦ I donâ€™t know. Just imagine some magic.

In such world viewâ€“i.e. a world view which connects the arrow of time with real-life forces that cause our world to changeâ€“ I also looked at the left- and right-handedness of particles as some kind of â€˜chargeâ€™, because it co-determines how the weak force plays out. Hence, any phenomenon in the movie having to do with the weak force (such as beta decay) could also be time-reversed by making left-handed particles right-handed, and right-handed particles left-handed. In short, I said that, when it comes to time reversal, only a full CPT-transformation makes senseâ€“from a philosophical point of view that is.

Now, reversing left- and right-handedness amounts to a P-transformation (and donâ€™t interrupt me now by asking why physicists use this rather awkward word â€˜parityâ€™ for whatâ€™s left- and right-handedness really), just like a C-transformation amounts to reversing electric and â€˜colorâ€™ charges (â€˜colorâ€™ charges are the charges involved in the strong nuclear force).

Now, if only a full CPT transformation makes sense, then CP-reversal should also mean T-reversal, and vice versa. Feynmanâ€™s story about â€œthe guy in the â€˜otherâ€™ universeâ€ (see my previous post) was quite instructive in that regard, and so letâ€™s look at the finer points of that story once again.

Is â€˜anotherâ€™ world possible at all?

Feynmanâ€™s assumption was that weâ€™ve made contact (donâ€™t ask how: somehow) with some other intelligent being living in some â€˜otherâ€™ world somewhere â€˜out thereâ€™, and that there are no visual or other common references. Thatâ€™s all rather vague, youâ€™ll say, but just hang in there and try to see where weâ€™re going with this story. Most notably, the other intelligent being â€“ but letâ€™s call â€˜itâ€™ a she instead of â€˜a guyâ€™ or â€˜a Martianâ€™ â€“ cannot see the universe as we see it: we canâ€™t describe, for instance, the Big and Small Dipper and explain to her what â€˜leftâ€™ and â€˜rightâ€™ is referring to such constellations, because sheâ€™s sealed off somehow from it (so she lives in a totally different corner of the universe really).

In contrast, we would be able, most probably, to explain and share the concept of â€˜upwardâ€™ and â€˜downwardsâ€™ by assuming that she is also attracted by some center of gravity nearby, just like we are attracted downwards by our Earth. Then, after many more hours and days, weeks, months or even years of tedious â€˜discussionsâ€™, we would probably be able to describe electric currents and explain electromagnetic phenomena, and then, hopefully, she would find out that the laws in her corner of the universe are exactly the same, and so we could thus explain and share the notion of a â€˜positiveâ€™ and a â€˜negativeâ€™ charge, and the notion of a magnetic â€˜northâ€™ and â€˜southâ€™ pole.

However, at this point the story becomes somewhat more complicated, because â€“ as I tried to explain in my previous post â€“ her â€˜positiveâ€™ electric charge (+) and her magnetic â€˜northâ€™ might well be our â€˜negativeâ€™ electric charge (â€“) and our magnetic â€˜southâ€™. Why? Itâ€™s simple: the electromagnetic force does respect charge and also parity symmetry and so there is no way of defining any absolute sense of â€˜leftâ€™ and â€˜rightâ€™ or (magnetic) â€˜northâ€™ and (magnetic) â€˜southâ€™ with reference to the electromagnetic force alone. [If you donâ€™t believe, just look at my previous post and study the examples.]

Talking about the strong force wouldnâ€™t help either, because it also fully respects charge symmetry.

Huh? Yes. Just go through my previous post which â€“ I admit â€“ was probably quite confusing but made the point that a â€˜mirror-imageâ€™ world would work just as wellâ€¦ except when it comes to the weak force. Indeed, atomic decay processes (beta decay) do distinguish between â€˜left-handedâ€™ and â€˜right-handedâ€™ particles (as measured by their spin) in an absolute sense that is (see the illustration of decaying muons and their mirror-image in the previous post) and, hence, itâ€™s simple: in order to make sure her â€˜leftâ€™ and her â€˜rightâ€™ is the same as ours, we should just ask her to perform those beta decay experiments demonstrating that parity (or P-symmetry) is not being conserved and, then, based on our common definition of whatâ€™s â€˜upâ€™ and â€˜downâ€™ (the commonality of these notions being based on the effects of gravity which, we assume, are the same in both worlds), we could agree that â€˜rightâ€™ is â€˜rightâ€™ indeed, and that â€˜leftâ€™ is â€˜leftâ€™ indeed.

Now, you will remember there was one â€˜catchâ€™ here: if ever we would want to set up an actual meeting with her (just assume that weâ€™ve finally figured out where she is and so we (or she) are on our way to meet each other), we would have to ask her to respect protocol and put out her right hand to greet us, not her left. The reason is the following: while â€˜right-handedâ€™ and â€˜left-handedâ€™ matter behave differently when it comes to weak force interactions (read: atomic decay processes)â€“which is how we can distinguish between â€˜leftâ€™ and â€˜rightâ€™ in the first place, in some kind of absolute sense that isâ€“the combined CP symmetry implies that right-handed matter and left-handed anti-matter behave just the sameâ€“and, of course, the same goes for â€˜left-handedâ€™ matter and â€˜right-handedâ€™ anti-matter. Hence, after we would have had a painstakingly long exchange on broken P-symmetry to ensure we are talking about the same thing, we would still not know for sure: she might be living in a world of anti-matter indeed, in which case her â€˜rightâ€™ would actually be â€˜leftâ€™ for us, and her â€˜leftâ€™ would be â€˜rightâ€™.

Hence, if, after all that talk on P-symmetry and doing all those experiments involving P-asymmetry, she actually would put out her left hand when meeting us physicallyâ€“instead of the agreed-upon right handâ€¦ Thenâ€¦ Wellâ€¦ Donâ€™t touch it. ğŸ™‚

There is a way out of course. And, who knows, perhaps she was just trying to be humorous and so perhaps she smiled and apologized for the confusion in the meanwhile. But thenâ€¦ [â€¦] Hmmâ€¦ I am not sure if such bad joke would make for a good start of a relationship, even if it would obviously demonstrate superior intelligence. ğŸ™‚

Indeed, the Fitch-Cronin experiment brings an additional twist to this potentially romantic story between two intelligent beings from two â€˜differentâ€™ worlds. In fact, the Fitch-Cronin experiment actually rules out this theoretical possibility of mutual destruction and, therefore, the possibility of two â€˜differentâ€™ worlds.

The argument goes straight to the heart of our philosophical discussion on time reversal. Indeed, whatever you may or may not have understood from this and my previous posts on CPT symmetry, the key point is that the combined CPT symmetry cannot be violated.

Why? Wellâ€¦ Thatâ€™s plain logic: the real world does not care about our conventions, so reversing all of our conventions, i.e.

Changing all particles to antiparticles by reversing all charges (C),

Turning all right-handed particles into left-handed particles and vice versa (P), and

Changing the sign of time (T),

describes a world truly going back in time.

Now, â€˜herâ€™ world is not going back in time. Why? Is this confusing? It sure is. But let me rephrase the logic. Perhaps it helps.

Combined CPT symmetry implies that if the combined CP-symmetry is broken, then T-symmetry is also broken. To put it simply: we cannot reverse time in a world which does not (fully) respect the principle of CP symmetry.

Now, if you and I can exchange meaningful signals (i.e. communicate), then your and my â€˜arrow of timeâ€™ obviously point in the same direction. To put it simply, weâ€™re actors in the same movie, and whether or not it is being played backwards doesnâ€™t matter anymore: the point is that the two of us share the same arrow of time. In other words, God did not do any combined CPT-transformation trick on your world as compared to mine, and vice versa.

Hence, â€˜yourâ€™ world is â€˜myâ€™ world and vice versa. So we live in the same world with the very same symmetries and asymmetries.

Now apply this logic to our imaginary new friend (â€˜sheâ€™) and (I hope) youâ€™ll get the point.

To make a long story short, and also to conclude our philosophical digressions here on a pleasant (romantic) note: the fact that we would be able to communicate with her, implies that sheâ€™d be living in the same world as ours. We know that now, for sure, because of the broken CP symmetry: indeed, if her â€˜time arrowâ€™ points in the same direction, then CP symmetry will be broken in just the very same way in â€˜herâ€™ world (i.e. the â€˜biasâ€™ will have the same direction, in an absolute sense) as it it is broken in â€˜ourâ€™ world.

In short, there are only two possible worlds: (1) this world and (2) one and only one â€˜otherâ€™ world. This â€˜otherâ€™ world is our world under a full CPT-transformation: the whole movie played backwards in other words, but with all â€˜chargesâ€™ affecting forces â€“ in whatever form and shape they come (electric charge, color charge, spin, and what have you) reversed or â€“ using that awful mathematical term â€“ â€˜negatedâ€™.

In case youâ€™d wonder (1): I consider the many-worlds interpretation of quantum mechanics asâ€¦ Wellâ€¦ Nonsense. CPT symmetry allows for two worlds only. Maximum two. ğŸ™‚

In case youâ€™d wonder (2): An oscillating-universe theory, or some kind of cyclic thing (so Big Bangs followed by Big Crunches) are not incompatible with my â€˜two-possible-worldsâ€™ view of things. However, this â€˜oscillationsâ€™ would all take place in the same world really, because the arrow of time isnâ€™t being reversed really, as Big Bangs and Big Crunches do not reverse charges and paritiesâ€“at least not to my knowledge.

There are at least two problems with this:

In previous posts, I mentioned the so-called Fitch-Cronin experiment which, back in 1964, provided evidence that â€˜Natureâ€™ also violated the combined CP-symmetry. In such simplistic world view, the question is not so much why the weak force violates mirror symmetry, but why gravity, electromagnetism and the strong force actually respect it!

Indeed, you donâ€™t get a Nobel Prize for stating the obvious and, hence, if Val Fitch and James Cronin got one for that CP-violation experiment, C/P or CP violation cannot be trivial matters.

P-symmetry revisited

So letâ€™s have another look at mirror symmetryâ€“also known as reflection symmetryâ€“ by following Feynmanâ€™s example: let us actually build a â€˜left-handâ€™ clock, and letâ€™s do it meticulously, as Feynman describes it: â€œEvery time there is a screw with a right-hand thread in one, we use a screw with a left-hand thread in the corresponding place of the other; where one is marked â€˜IVâ€™ on the face, we mark a â€˜VIâ€™ on the face of the other; each coiled spring is twisted one way in one clock and the other way in the mirror-image clock; when we are all finished, we have two clocks, both physical, which bear to each other the relation of an object and its mirror image, although they are both actual, material objects. Now the question is: If the two clocks are started in the same condition, the springs wound to corresponding tightnesses, will the two clocks tick and go around, forever after, as exact mirror images?â€

The answer seems to be obvious: of course they will! Indeed, we do observe that P symmetry is being respected, as shown below:

You may wonder why we have to go through the trouble of building another clock. Why canâ€™t we just take one of these transparent â€˜mystery clocksâ€™ and just go around it and watch its hand(s) move standing behind it? The answer is simple: thatâ€™s not what mirror symmetry is about. As Feynman puts its: a mirror reflection â€œturns the whole space inside out.â€ So itâ€™s not like a simple translation or a rotation of space. Indeed, when we would move around the clock to watch it from behind, then all we do is rotating our reference frame (with a rotation angle equal to 180 degrees). Thatâ€™s all.
